facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 14th January, 1972 of the Orissa High Court in Election Petition No. 8 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 402 of 1972 Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 14th January, 1972 of the Orissa High Court in Election Petition No. 8 of 1971.

facts.text: Respondent elected to Lok Sabha from Kendrapara parliamentary constituency, Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents numberinee of the Utkal Congress of which Biju Patnaik an ex-Chief Minister of the, Orissa State is the founder leader-was elected to the Lok Sabha from the Kendrapara parliamentary companystituency in that State,

facts.text: Respondent Surendra Mohanty polled 1,23,680 votes; Surendranath Dwivedi 1,20,707 votes; Pradyumna Kishore Bal 1,11,235 votes.

anchor.surface_text: by defeating two candidates, namely Surendranath Dwivedi-a numberinee of the Praja Socialist Party-and Pradyamna Kishore Bal a numberinee of the Indian National Congress  R  Party. At this election the respondent Surendra Mohanty polled 1,23,680 votes, Surendranath Dwivedi 1,20,707 votes and Pradyumna Kishore Bal 1, 1 1,23 5 votes.

facts.text: Appellant, a voter in Kendrapara constituency, challenged respondent's election alleging corrupt practices under ss. 3 and 4 of S. 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- a voter in that companystituency-challenged the election of- the, respondent on the ground that companyrupt practices under sub-ss,  3  and  4  of S. 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951-hereinafter referred to as the Act-which were detailed in sub-paragraphs  i  to  iv  of paragraphs of the petition were companymitted by him and or by his agents with his companysent.

facts.text: Orissa High Court dismissed the election petition after trial.

anchor.surface_text: The petition, after it was duly tried, was dismissed by the High Court, against which this appeal has been filed under S. 116A of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent was editor of Oriya Daily 'The Kalinga' published by Kalinga Publications, Chairman Biju Patnaik.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the respondent was at all material times, and even at the date of the, election petition, an editor of an Oriya Daily The Kalingal published by the Kalinga Publications whose Chairman is Biju Patnaik.

facts.text: Utkal Congress symbol: water wheel 'Chakra' and plough 'Langala'.

anchor.surface_text: As one of the companyrupt practices alleged against the respondent has relevance to the election symbol, it is necessary to state that the symbol allotted to the Utkal Congress was the water wheel  Chakra  and the plough  Langala .

facts.text: Editorial in The Kalinga dated February 15, 1971 appealed to religious symbols Chakra and Langala associated with Jagannath and Balaram.

anchor.surface_text: i  that the respondent who was the editor of an Oriya Daily The Kalinga published in his paper dated February 15, 1971, an editorial appealing to the religious symbol of Chakra and Langala the mythological weapons associated with Jagannath and Balaram the most worshiped and esteemed deities in Orissa for the furtherance of the prospects of his election and for prejudicially affecting the election of other candidates.

facts.text: Biju Patnaik at public meeting on February 15, 1971 at 5 P.M. at Marshaghai appealed to religious symbols by referencing Jagannath and Balaram.

anchor.surface_text: paragraph 5 i  of the petition  that Biju Patnaik in a public meeting held on February 15, 1971, at 5 P.M. had appealed to religious symbol by saying that his party  Utkal Congress  was fully able to eradicate unemployment and poverty from the companyntry by forming a strong Government in the State with the help of the two powers Jagannath and Balaram whose weapons Chakra and Langala have been chosen by Utkal Congress as its symbol.

facts.text: Report in The Kalinga dated February 19, 1971 published appeal to religious symbols from Feb 15 meeting.

anchor.surface_text: paragraph 5 iii  of the petition  and that the respondent in his daily paper The Kalinga dated February 19, 1971 had published a report regarding the meeting held at Marshaghai on February 15, 1971, companytaining the aforesaid appeal to religious symbol as detailed in  i  above.

facts.text: Respondent at public meeting Feb 15, 1971 at Marshaghai made false statements about Surendranath Dwivedi not rendering accounts of one lakh rupees from Marwari Society, Bombay and Rs. 25,000 from Prime Minister during 1967 cyclone.

anchor.surface_text: The allegations in respect of the second category are that on February 15, 1971 in a public meeting held at 5 M. at Marshaghai the respondent made false statements of facts regarding the personal character and companyduct of Surendranath Dwivedi to the following effect which the respondent believed to be false and or did number believe to be true - Shri Surendranath Dwivedi has number yet rendered account of the gift of one lakh rupees from the Marwari Society, Bombay, and Rs. 25,000/- from the Prime Minister brought by him during the cyclone of 1967 for the relief of the people.

facts.text: Report in The Kalinga Feb 19, 1971 contained false statement about Dwivedi's character from Feb 15 meeting.

anchor.surface_text: and that the report regarding the said meeting of February 15, 1971 companytaining a false statement in relation to the personal character or companyduct of Surendranath Dwivedi as detailed above  in paragraph 5 ii  of the petition  was published in his daily paper The Kalinga dated February 19, 1971 by the respondent or with his companysent by his subordinates.

facts.text: Respondent denied all allegations of corrupt practices in para 8 of written statement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in paragraph-8 of his written statement denied the allegations of companyrupt practices said to have been companymitted by him.

facts.text: Respondent admitted being editor of The Kalinga but denied involvement in editorial Feb 15 or report Feb 19, no consent or agency.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent while admitting he was the editor of The Kalinga at all material times stated that he had numberhing to do with the editorial of February 15, 1971 or with the publication of the news report of February 19, 1971, number did he authorise or companysent to any one publishing them number those who published them were his agents.

facts.text: Respondent on leave from Jan 19, 1971 till end of elections; J. Verma, News Editor, in charge per letter Ext. L dated Jan 15, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondent is that while numberdoubt he was the editor of the Kalinga during the relevant period and his name was number only shown as such in the issues of February 15 and February 19, 1971, and there was numberchange in the declaration made by him under the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867, he remained absent and his work was done by Verma. In support of this companytention he produced a letter of January 15, 1971  Ext. L  addressed to the Chairman of The Kalinga Press, Biju Patnaik,

facts.text: Orissa High Court disbelieved petitioner's witnesses on Feb 15 meeting attendance and statements.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disbelieved the evidence of the witnesses on behalf of the petitioner who said that they had attended the meeting held on February 15, 1971, at Marshaghai.

facts.text: High Court believed respondent's evidence that he did not make alleged statements and had no concern with publications Ext.1 and Ext.2.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it believed the evidence of the witnesses produced on behalf of the respondent as also the respondents own evidence that in the meeting held on February 15, 1971 the respondent had number stated as alleged number having regard to the working arrangements as disclosed by Exts. L, L/2 and L/3 did he have any companycern with the publication or the editorial Ext.1 or the news report Ext. 2,

facts.text: High Court held alleged statement related to public conduct, not personal character of Dwivedi.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court inter alia further held that in any event the alleged statement of the respondent asking Dwivedi to render accounts related to the public companyduct of Dwivedi and number to his personal character or companyduct.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court findings, dismissed appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we do number think it necessary to go into the other questions. As the appellant has number made out any of the allegations of companyrupt practices against the respondent, this appeal will be dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: No corrupt practice proved; publications not with respondent's consent; speech related to public conduct.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that asking Dwivedi to render accounts in respect of the amounts companylected for the cyclone and flood relief purpose was an expression of opinion and related to the public companyduct and did number amount to any imputation against the personal character or companyduct of Dwivedi.

facts.text: Public controversy in Prajatantra about Dwivedi rendering accounts of relief funds collected.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent further averred that in the said meeting at Marshaghai held at about 7 P.M. on February 15, 1971 he had merely referred to a public companytroversy as to the public duty of Dwivedi to render accounts of the money received by or through him for relief work from outside the State including the Bihar Relief Committee.

facts.text: J. Verma admitted in evidence that he was in charge from Jan 19, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Verma, R.W. 3 has admitted this document and has also admitted that from January 19, 1971, the respondent did number have anything to do with writing of editorials or publication of the Kalinga.

facts.text: Supreme Court found respondent rebutted presumption under Press Act s.7 via evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It will have to be seen whether on the evidence the respondent has bee successful in rebutting the presumption under the, Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867.

facts.text: Petitioner's witnesses unreliable, parroted same story, improved on pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the statements of these witnesses shows that in the first instance the allegation that the respondent said that Dwivedi had appropriated  Mari Nele  that money and had number rendered any accounts therefor. A perusal of the statements of these witnesses shows that in the first instance the allegation that the respondent said that Dwivedi had appropriated or misappropriated the amounts is an improvement from the allegations in the pleadings,

facts.text: Dwivedi did not receive money directly from Marwari Society or PM for 1967 cyclone.

anchor.surface_text: In fact Dwivedi was responsible for getting Rs. 20,000/- from the Prime Minister for rebuilding a school which had been destroyed in the cyclone. Even this money was number paid to him but was,routed through the Chief Minister and given to school directly.

arguments.claim: To prove corrupt practice under s.123(3)/100(1)(b)/(d)(ii), must prove made by candidate/agent/with consent, and for religious appeal/furtherance/prejudice; for s.123(4) false re personal character etc.

anchor.surface_text: Clauses b and d ii of sub-s. 1 of s. 100 of the Act deal with corrupt practices, while s. 123 of the Act sets out what shall be deemed to be corrupt practices... [lists requirements]

arguments.claim: Agent defined in Expl to s.123 includes any acting with consent

anchor.surface_text: The word agent under the Explanation to S. 123 of the Act includes ,an election agent, a polling agent and any person who is held to have acted as an agent in connection with the election with the consent of the candidate.

arguments.claim: Different burdens: by candidate/election agent/with consent avoids election; by other agent needs material effect (citing Samant N Balakrishna)

anchor.surface_text: In Samant N. Balakrishna etc. v. George Fernandez and Ors. etc. Hidayatullah, C.J., dealing with different burdens of proof...

arguments.claim: Press s.7 presumption rebuttable by evidence, not only s.8A

anchor.surface_text: Though s. 7 raises a presumption that- a person whose name is printed in a copy of the newspaper is the editor of every portion of that issue, that presumption may be rebutted by evidence.

arguments.claim: Pleadings need material facts only, not evidence (s.83(b)); misappropriation allegation new, inadmissible

anchor.surface_text: This allegation of misappropriation being a material fact ought to have been stated in the pleadings as required in S. 83 b and no evidence contrary to the pleadings can be led or considered because it changes the complexion of corrupt practice.

arguments.claim: Asking to render public relief accounts is public conduct, not personal (no corrupt practice)

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that asking Dwivedi to render accounts in respect of the amounts companylected for the cyclone and flood relief purpose was an expression of opinion and related to the public companyduct and did number amount to any imputation against the personal character or companyduct of Dwivedi.

arguments.claim: No corrupt practices proved; appeal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we do number think it necessary to go into the other questions. As the appellant has number made out any of the allegations of companyrupt practices against the respondent, this appeal will be dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: The presumption under section 7 of the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867, that the person whose name is printed as editor is the editor of every portion of that issue, is rebuttable by evidence and is not limited to the procedure under section 8A.

anchor.surface_text: Though s. 7 raises a presumption that- a person whose name is printed in a copy of the newspaper is the editor of every portion of that issue, that presumption may be rebutted by evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites D.P. Mishra case where similar presumption rebutted by evidence of delegation; distinguishes purpose of Press Act from election law proof requirements.

holdings.text: Exts. 1 and 2 (editorial and news report) were not published by the respondent or with his consent, as he was on leave with J. Verma in charge per Ext. L, rebutting s.7 presumption.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the working arrangements as disclosed by Exts. L, L/2 and L/3 did he have any concern with the publication or the editorial Ext.1 or the news report Ext. 2, nor can the consent or complicity of the respondent be presumed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of leave letter Ext.L endorsed by chairman and Verma; RW3 admission; objections to authenticity rejected; no need for manuscript or further proof.

holdings.text: Biju Patnaik's alleged speech appealing to religious symbols was not made with the respondent's consent, and Patnaik was not his agent.

anchor.surface_text: the case of the respondent is that he had left the meeting before Biju Patnaik addressed the same and he was, therefore, not present when Biju Patnaik addressed that meeting.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent left early for another meeting; no evidence of consent or agency despite relationship; consent not inferred from friendship or affiliation, citing D.P. Mishra.

holdings.text: No corrupt practice u/s 123(3) proved, as no publication by/with consent of respondent and no consent to Patnaik's speech.

anchor.surface_text: When once it is established that neither the editorial Ext. 1 nor the news report Ext. 2 were published by the respondent or by some one else with his consent or that the speech alleged to be made by Biju Patnaik...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails agency/consent requirement u/s 123(3) and 100(1)(b)/(d)(ii); unnecessary to decide if content was corrupt practice.

holdings.text: Allegation of misappropriation by respondent not proved and inadmissible as not pleaded as material fact u/s 83(b).

anchor.surface_text: This allegation of misappropriation being a material fact ought to have been stated in the pleadings as required in S. 83 b and no evidence contrary to the pleadings can be led or considered

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleadings require summary of material facts, not evidence; unpleaded misappropriation changes corrupt practice nature; PW evidence improvement on pleadings rejected.

holdings.text: Asking Dwivedi to render accounts of public relief funds relates to public conduct, not personal character/conduct u/s 123(4).

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the High Court that asking Dwivedi to render accounts in respect of the amounts collected for the cyclone and flood relief purpose was an expression of opinion and related to the public conduct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public demand in controversy (Exts.3,4,A,5); moral duty of public figure; no imputation of dishonesty without more; even if made, not corrupt practice.

holdings.text: Petitioner's witnesses unreliable; parroted identical story, improved on pleadings; High Court evidence findings upheld.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the statements of these witnesses shows that in the first instance the allegation that the respondent said that Dwivedi had appropriated or misappropriated the amounts is an improvement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform repetition without context; contradicted by RW4 (reporter); demeanor noted by trial court; appellate deference to findings.

holdings.text: No corrupt practices u/ss.123(3),(4) proved against respondent; election petition and appeal dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails on consent, agency, falsity, personal character elements; petitioner bears burden unmet.

precedents.citation: Samant N. Balakrishna etc. v. George Fernandez and Ors. etc. 1 1969 3 S.C.R. 603

anchor.surface_text: In Samant N. Balakrishna etc. v. George Fernandez and Ors. etc. 1 Hidayatullah, C.J., dealing with different burdens of proof as to whether an offending statement was made by the candidate himself or by his agent other than an election agent observed at p. 619 There are many kinds of companyrupt practices . . .

precedents.case_name: Samant N. Balakrishna v. George Fernandez
precedents.cited_proposition: Different burdens of proof for corrupt practices committed by candidate or election agent versus agent other than election agent
precedents.cited_holding: The first class consists of corrupt practices committed by the candidate or his election agent or any other person with the consent of the candidate or his election agent. These, if established, avoid the election without any further condition being fulfilled. Then there is the corrupt practice committed by an agent other than an election agent. Here an additional fact has to be proved that the result of the election was materially affected.

precedents.citation: D. P. Mishra v. Kamal Narain Sharma Ors. 1 1971 3 S.C.R. 257

anchor.surface_text: In D. P. Mishra v. Kamal Narain Sharma Ors. 1 after this Court had directed the giving of a numberice to Shukla 1 1971 3 S.C.R. 257. who was an editor, publisher and printer of Mahakoshall which published material relevant to the personal character as to why he should number be named under S. 98 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: D. P. Mishra v. Kamal Narain Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: Editor of newspaper can rebut presumption of responsibility under Press and Registration of Books Act by evidence that publication was without his knowledge or consent
precedents.cited_holding: unless there was evidence to prove that Shukla had either authorised the publication of the offending matter or had undertaken to be responsible for all the publications made in the Mahakoshal, no inference that the offending publications were made with the knowledge and with the consent of Shukla could be drawn.

anchor.surface_text: As pointedout in D. P. Mishras case 1 however close the relationship, unless there is evidence to prove that the person publishing or writing the editorial was authorised by the returned candidate or he had undertaken to be responsible for all the publications, numberconsent can be inferred. That Tarangi was in full charge of the publication of the Mahakoshal does number distinguish that case from the facts of this case where R.W. 3 also was in full charge of the Kalinga during the respondents absence.

precedents.case_name: D. P. Mishra v. Kamal Narain Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: Consent or agency cannot be inferred merely from close relationship or political affiliation without evidence of authorisation
precedents.cited_holding: however close the relationship, unless there is evidence to prove that the person publishing or writing the editorial was authorised by the returned candidate or he had undertaken to be responsible for all the publications, no consent can be inferred.
